Fostering Deep Thinking: Discussion Techniques Facilitator: Jen Wilson, Ph.D. | Director of OEDD, AdvancED Buttrick 101 In this session we will consider some of the most significant challenges to leading generative and meaningful discussions and how we may overcome. We will explore a variety of techniques for organizing class discussions, effective methods of facilitation, and approaches to assessment that enable critical reflection and improvement. By modeling some discussion leading practices and providing useful resources, this workshop will help you to engage students more fully and find greater joy in teaching. Teaching in the Time of Artificial Intelligence Facilitators: Marcy Pedzwater, Ph.D . | Instructional Design Manager, AdvancED Buttrick 102 (Auditorium) Few issues have garnered as much attention from educators in recent months as the growth of AI and its impacts on teaching and learning in higher education. In this session we will discuss some of the challenges and opportunities that AI presents for our students’ learning, and some valuable teaching techniques that we may embrace to help them, both avoid its misuse, and leverage its strengths for their intellectual growth. Supporting Student Belonging Facilitator: Boni Yraguen, Ph.D . | Instructional Consultant, AdvancED Buttrick 201 In this session, we will discuss some research-supported strategies for promoting diverse students’ sense of belonging and deeper engagement with course content, including approaches developed by Vanderbilt faculty.  We will also consider how instructors can share power with their students while supporting them in developing closer relationships with each other throughout the semester and beyond. Participants will be provided with resources and contacts to support their continued personal growth around issues of equity, diversity, and educational justice in higher education. Balancing Teaching and Research: Effective Course Management Strategies Facilitator: Bryson McGuire, Ed .D. | Manager of Teaching Development and Initiatives, AdvancED Buttrick 202 Balancing teaching and research responsibilities is a common challenge for many faculty members. Striking the right balance is essential for both faculty success and well-being. Effective course management ensures that teaching responsibilities are handled efficiently, leaving more time and energy for research activities. This workshop is designed to address this critical issue by providing practical strategies for managing courses and balancing teaching responsibilities with research commitments. Participants will learn how to efficiently manage their teaching duties while maintaining a robust research agenda, ultimately leading to a more fulfilling and productive academic career. This session will equip participants with the tools and techniques needed to achieve this balance, fostering both personal and professional growth. The Student Care Network and Supporting Students in Distress Facilitators: Lisa Clapper, Director, Student Care Network, & Katherine Drotos Cuthbert, Assistant Director, Center for Student Wellbeing Buttrick 112 The Student Care Network is a holistic network of wellbeing resources designed to support the health and well-being of all Vanderbilt students. Learn more about the Student Care Network, how to best connect students with these helpful resources, and how to help support students who experience personal challenges and severe distress. More details on our consultations can be found here . Additional Resources New and returning faculty members are invited to join our ongoing programs and workshops. Topics include leading class discussions, syllabus design, presentation tools, inclusive teaching, educational technologies, and more. Information can be found on our events page . Learn more Accept Vanderbilt University Vanderbilt University Menu AdvancED: The Institute for the Advancement of Higher Education Home About What We Do Digital & Lifelong Learning Educational Technology Scholarly & Innovative Teaching Resources Brightspace Support Digital Media Services Educational Technology Resources Events & News Events News Close Menu Vanderbilt University AdvancED: The Institute for the Advancement of Higher Education All Vanderbilt Home About What We Do Digital & Lifelong Learning Educational Technology Scholarly & Innovative Teaching Resources Brightspace Support Digital Media Services Educational Technology Resources Events & News Events News About This is Vanderbilt Quick Facts University Leadership Equity, Diversity & Inclusion History Contact A to Z Admissions Undergraduate Admissions Graduate & Professional School Admissions Financial Aid Academics Program Finder Schools & Colleges Residential Colleges Study Abroad Libraries Strategic Plan Research Centers & Institutes Research News Undergraduate Research Graduate School Research VUMC Research Campus Life Housing & Dining Health & Safety Organizations & Identity Centers Athletics Our Hometown - Nashville News & Events Vanderbilt News Research News Vanderbilt Magazine Events Teaching Assistant Orientation On this page Program Details Eligibility Graduate students balance many roles: student, researcher, teacher, mentor and more! One important role a graduate student may hold in their time at VU is that of a teaching assistant. While teaching assistant (TA) duties vary across departments, they all demand considerable skill and knowledge. These duties can include grading, consulting with students during office hours, leading discussion or problem sessions, teaching labs or giving lectures. To assist new TAs as they prepare for their duties, AdvancED’s Office of Educational Design and Development (OEDD) will offer Teaching Assistant Orientation (TAO) each August. TAO sessions offer effective strategies for the varied teaching duties assumed by TAs and provide information on campus resources available to TAs. Participants at TAO also receive an opportunity to practice their teaching skills and receive feedback on their teaching from experienced teachers. Participation in the orientation can make students’ work as TAs easier and will be a valuable addition to their curriculum vitae. Participation in the TAO develops transferable skills valuable for a wide range of careers, including effective communication, classroom management, problem-solving and time management. Unable to attend TAO on August 14? Enroll in our Asynchronous Teaching Assistant Orientation on Brightspace! This orientation is self-paced so TAs may access and work through this resource at a time that best fits within their busy schedules. In this orientation, TAs will explore: TA Roles and Responsibilities Active Learning Strategies Grading and Feedback Helpful Policies and Resources Upon completion, TAs will earn a badge which they can share with their supervisor and/or director of graduate studies, as applicable. Enroll in Self-paced TAO on Brightspace How to Enroll: Navigate to the Brightspace homepage In the navbar along the top of the page, select More and choose Self Registration Find the Teaching Assistant Orientation 2024 course Select the Register button to begin the registration process Your information will be automatically populated in the registration form. Select Submit Select Finish to complete your registration Once you've completed these steps, you'll have access to this course from the Brightspace homepage via the Self-Registration Courses tab. If you encounter any technical issues enrolling in the course, please contact Brightspace support at brightspace@vanderbilt.edu . Enroll in Self-paced TAO on Brightspace Program Details TAO is now in-person! Wednesday, August 14, 2024 | 10am - 5:30pm Location: Featheringill Jacobs Hall New for August 2024, AdvancED will be hosting an in-person Teaching Assistant Orientation. This one-day event on Wednesday, August 14, is designed for new and returning TAs, providing them with valuable information and skills to navigate a range of topics, from university policies to giving constructive feedback during grading. TAO participants will have the opportunity to customize their experience by selecting three workshops tailored to their current TA responsibilities. They also will hear from experienced TAs who will share insights on successfully navigating the role, as well as receive training from institutional leaders and experts on evidence-based teaching and learning practices. Participants can expect to leave with a set of actionable tools they can immediately apply in their roles as TAs. Eligibility Graduate students who will begin teaching assistant (TA) duties during the 2024-25 school year . Graduate students who have previous TA experience but will be returning as a TA during the 2024-25 school year. Some graduate students opt in to TAO, while some are required to attend TAO by their department. Please check with your department to find out its TAO attendance policy. If you do not know if you will begin your TA duties during the 2024-25 school year, then you should check with your department to find out. Facultywishingto grow their skills in order to amplify their impact in the classroom

Applying Gamification in Your Classroom (3-part series)Facilitated by Brian DeLevie, Ed.D.September 5, 2:30 p.m. - 4:30 p.m. (120 mins)September 12, 2:30 p.m. - 4:00 p.m. (90 mins)September 19, 2:30 p.m. - 4:00 p.m. (90 mins)Revolutionize your teaching with the power of gamification in this engaging 3-part series. Experience the benefits of game mechanics and elements in designing compelling courses and lessons. Participate in hands-on activities, receive personalized feedback, and create a gamified structure tailored to your classroom. Transform your teaching environment into an interactive and motivating space that captivates students.

Enhancing Student Engagement Through Inclusion Awareness and Strategic ResponseFacilitated by Bryson McGuire, Ed.D.September 17, 10:45 a.m. - 12:15 p.m. (90 mins)Dive into the crucial connection between inclusive teaching practices and student engagement. This workshop offers an in-depth exploration of how inclusive decision-making impacts student interest and addresses disengagement. Through case study analysis and the ladder of inference, you’ll practice applying inclusive strategies, creating a supportive and engaging learning environment for all students.

Inclusive Assessments and GradingFacilitated by Jen Wilson, Ph.D.September 24, 12:15 p.m. - 1:15 p.m. (60 mins)Transform your assessment practices with this workshop on inclusive grading. Distinguish between formative and summative assessments and explore innovative strategies for creating equitable assessments. Discover how to design assignments and rubrics that celebrate diverse student strengths and promote fairness across various student backgrounds.

Steal My Success StrategyFacilitated by Jen Wilson, Ph.D. and Meg Pilkenton, Ph.D.October 3, 10:45 a.m. - 12:15 p.m. (90 mins)Join this dynamic workshop to exchange and explore successful teaching strategies with your peers. Share your own proven techniques and learn from the experiences of others. Leave with a new, impactful strategy to implement in your classroom, expanding your pedagogical toolkit with insights gained from a collaborative discussion.

Navigating Difficult Conversations in the ClassroomFacilitated by Bryson McGuire, Ed.D.October 14, 9:15 a.m. - 10:45 a.m. (90 mins)Develop your skills for handling sensitive and challenging discussions with students in this essential workshop. Learn two key techniques for facilitating difficult conversations while fostering a safe and inclusive classroom atmosphere. Discover strategies to manage conflicts effectively and promote open, respectful communication among students, enhancing the overall classroom experience.

Lowering the Stakes While Raising the Standards: Un-grading in Higher EducationFacilitated by BoniYraguen, Ph.D.October 24, 12:15 p.m. - 1:15 p.m. (60 mins)Transform your approach to assessment with the innovative concept of "ungrading." This workshop introduces you to ungrading, exploring its benefits and potential challenges. Leave with 2-3 practical strategies for implementing ungrading in your teaching, shifting the focus from grades to learning outcomes, and fostering a growth mindset among your students.

Accelerating Assessment: How to Measure Learning Without Wasting TimeFacilitated byMeg PilkentonOctober 29, 2024 at 10:10 AM - 11:10 AM (60 minutes)In this workshop, we will explore creative solutions to the age-old problem of grading quickly while still grading well. Participants will learn about and/or develop their own strategies for performing meaningful, goals-aligned assessments under a variety of extenuating circumstances, such as large classes with no TAs, final projects with complex learning objectives, or in-class presentations that eat up class time.

Mastering Mentorship: Strategies for Supporting Graduate Students through ChallengesFacilitated by BoniYraguen, Ph.D.February 11, 10:45 a.m. - 12:15 p.m. (90 mins)Enhance your mentorship skills with this workshop focused on the complexities of guiding graduate students. Explore the dynamics of academic mentoring, including power relationships and effective strategies for overcoming challenges. Equip yourself with the tools to support your graduate students' personal and professional growth, ensuring a successful mentorship experience.

Using Brightspace and Integrated Brightspace Tools to Support Capstone ProjectsFacilitated by the ID TeamFebruary 13, 12:15 p.m. - 1:15 p.m. (60 mins)Maximize the potential of Brightspace for your Capstone projects with this practical workshop. Develop and draft online check-point projects and utilize Brightspace tools to design engaging activities and assessments tailored to your courses. Enhance your Capstone projects with innovative technology solutions that support and elevate student learning.

Balancing Teaching and Research: Strategies for Effective Course Management and Student EngagementFacilitated by Bryson McGuire, Ed.D.February 25, 10:10 a.m. - 11:10 a.m. (60 mins)Struggling to juggle teaching responsibilities with research demands? This workshop is designed to help you master the art of balance. Discover three powerful strategies for effective course management and delve into a case study that clarifies how to align your teaching and research commitments. Learn to harmonize these essential aspects of academia, ensuring that both your classroom performance and research thrive.

Generative AI in the ClassroomFacilitated by Jen Wilson, Ph.D.March 3, 10:10 a.m. - 11:10 a.m. (60 mins)Explore the future of teaching with generative artificial intelligence in this cutting-edge workshop. Review real-world examples of AI applications in the classroom, identify effective approaches for course assignments, and practice using AI as a tutor or coach. Harness the transformative potential of AI tools to enhance your teaching methods and improve student learning experiences.

Empowering Teaching and Learning through Human Centered Design (HCD)Facilitated by the ID TeamMarch 20, 12:15 p.m. - 1:15 p.m. (60 mins)Discover the advantages of Human Centered Design (HCD) for enhancing your teaching practices. This workshop will guide you in integrating HCD principles into both in-person and online learning environments. Learn to create student-centered learning experiences that prioritize the needs and preferences of your learners, leading to more effective and engaging educational outcomes.

Using Universal Design of Learning Principles to Improve the Accessibility of Your Learning Materials and Brightspace EnvironmentFacilitated by the ID TeamMarch 25, 2:30 p.m. - 3:30 p.m. (60 mins)Enhance the accessibility of your course materials and Brightspace environment by applying Universal Design for Learning (UDL) principles. Learn about the significant impact of UDL on student outcomes and implement three transformative strategies to make your learning materials and digital environment more inclusive and accessible for all learners.

We are also available during the academic year to facilitate Brightspace workshops on topics both general and specific for departments, programs, and schools, upon request. Email brightspace@vanderbilt.edu to ask about these offerings or the possibility of an invited workshop. See the main AdvancED website for other teaching workshops, including workshops focused on educational technology. Click here to go directly to our Workshop Calendar. Fall 2024 Workshops Setting up your Brightspace Course Join us for this hands-on workshop designed as a boot camp to get your course up and running. Explore building modules, uploading your syllabus, and mastering essential tools that will empower your online teaching experience. Participants who would like to access Brightspace during the workshop should make sure they are able to log into Brightspace with their VUnetID beforehand. No current workshops scheduled These workshops are open to anyone teaching or developing courses at Vanderbilt University. Vanderbilt University is committed to providing universal access to all of our events. Please contact the EdTech Team at brightspace@vanderbilt.edu to request disability accommodations. Advance notice is necessary to arrange for some accessibility needs. Brightspace Tools for Student Engagement Discover strategies to enhance student engagement in your course by leveraging tools like discussions and peer assessment. Gain insights into optimizing your homepage with practical tips and techniques to create an inviting and visually appealing learning environment. No current workshops scheduled These workshops are open to anyone teaching or developing courses at Vanderbilt University. Vanderbilt University is committed to providing universal access to all of our events. Please contact the EdTech Team at brightspace@vanderbilt.edu to request disability accommodations. Advance notice is necessary to arrange for some accessibility needs. Grading & Assessment Tools This comprehensive workshop is designed to provide you with a step-by-step approach to effectively grade quizzes and assignments, create rubrics tailored to your instructional goals, and set up your gradebook to accurately reflect student progress and achievement. Wednesday, October 9: 10 AM – 11:30 AM, In person (Baker Building, 805 Large conference room) These workshops are open to anyone teaching or developing courses at Vanderbilt University. To register for our Grading & Assessment Tools workshop, complete the online registration form here . Vanderbilt University is committed to providing universal access to all of our events. Please contact the EdTech Team at brightspace@vanderbilt.edu to request disability accommodations. Advance notice is necessary to arrange for some accessibility needs. Peer Sharing Join our Peer Sharing event where faculty can showcase innovative and effective uses of Brightspace. Whether you’re eager to share your own experiences or keen to learn from others, we invite you to attend. Monday, November 11 – 2 PM – 4 PM – In Person (Baker building) This event is open to anyone teaching or developing courses at Vanderbilt University. To register for our Peer Sharing event, complete the online registration form here . Vanderbilt University is committed to providing universal access to all of our events. Please contact the EdTech Team at brightspace@vanderbilt.edu to request disability accommodations. Advance notice is necessary to arrange for some accessibility needs. Educational Technology Workshops & Trainings Calendar Brightspace Frequently Asked Questions Check out our newly updated Brightspace FAQs ! This list runs through the most common questions the Brightspace Support Team gets throughout the year. If you have any questions not listed here, be sure to contact our Support team for assistance. New Support Schedule The Brightspace Support team has updated our support schedule. We are available for support between 9AM and 5PM Monday through Friday. Any emails received after 5PM will be addressed when the team returns to support at 9AM the following business day. While we’re out, we encourage you to utilize our On-Demand Resources to answer any questions that arise. Learn more Accept Vanderbilt University Vanderbilt University Menu AdvancED: The Institute for the Advancement of Higher Education Home About What We Do Digital & Lifelong Learning Educational Technology Scholarly & Innovative Teaching Resources Brightspace Support Digital Media Services Educational Technology Resources Events & News Events News Close Menu Vanderbilt University AdvancED: The Institute for the Advancement of Higher Education All Vanderbilt Home About What We Do Digital & Lifelong Learning Educational Technology Scholarly & Innovative Teaching Resources Brightspace Support Digital Media Services Educational Technology Resources Events & News Events News About This is Vanderbilt Quick Facts University Leadership Equity, Diversity & Inclusion History Contact A to Z Admissions Undergraduate Admissions Graduate & Professional School Admissions Financial Aid Academics Program Finder Schools & Colleges Residential Colleges Study Abroad Libraries Strategic Plan Research Centers & Institutes Research News Undergraduate Research Graduate School Research VUMC Research Campus Life Housing & Dining Health & Safety Organizations & Identity Centers Athletics Our Hometown - Nashville News & Events Vanderbilt News Research News Vanderbilt Magazine Events About On this page Our Mission Our Focus Areas Impact Report Our Team Connect Our Mission The Institute for the Advancement of Higher Education, or AdvancED, exists to promote cutting-edge, research-backed innovations in pedagogy and student experience to maximize the impact of new ideas on society. Part of Vanderbilt’s Office of Faculty Affairs and Professional Education, AdvancED combines the talent and expertise of the Office of Education Design and Development and Office of Learning Innovation and is organized around three primary focus areas including, instructional development, learning innovation, and student success. Our Focus Areas Instructional Development From deepening your teaching practice and pedagogical approaches to designing research-informed classroom experiences, AdvancED serves Vanderbilt’s faculty through faculty development and training. Learning Innovation AdvancED works closely with faculty to design and innovate uniquely Vanderbilt educational solutions that meet the needs of an expanding and evolving community of learners. Student Success AdvancED works closely with faculty, departments, schools and colleges to meet learning objectives, outcomes, and support and maximize success for all Vanderbilt students. Impact Report As the inaugural impact report for AdvancED, we have compiled a comprehensive overview of our achievements, progress and the inspiring initiatives we’ve embarked on over the past year. With a small yet mighty team committed to fostering innovation and pedagogical excellence, we set out to engage with Vanderbilt faculty and the broader community. Our mission is to equip our community with the tools and information necessary to leap into the future and cultivate a passion for lifelong learning. Delve into our report to discover how you can take the next step with our team and dare to grow. Promotecampus-wide collaboration between leaders, teachers, and learners.

Syllabus and Course DesignCourse design review is a valuable first step as you plan your courses and can bring an holistic and intentional approach to the development of multiple course components: your teaching philosophy, learning goals, assignments, learning activities, lesson plans, engagement techniques planning, course policies, or writing your syllabus, just to name a few.

Instructional DesignWe can help you develop well-designed courses in Brightspace, Vanderbilt's learning management system, that can lead students to experience greater understanding, accessibility, organization, self-efficacy, and success.

Teaching ObservationObservations can be a highly valuable way to identify strengths and possible growth areas in your techniques of lecturing, leading discussions, designing lesson plans, engaging students, fostering inclusion and belonging, and countless other skills. This can be a way to become a more reflective and intentional teacher, and generate new ideas for effectively meeting your goals. This involves scheduling both an observation and a one-hour debrief.

Technology ConsultationOur team can help you think of what, if any, educational technology might help you innovate and better achieve your teaching goals, including Brightspace, Vanderbilt's learning management system, its associated tools, communications and networking technologies, presentation platforms, classroom response systems, audio/video technology, artificial intelligence, and much more.

Teaching PortfolioWe can help you reflect, assess, and develop a teaching philosophy, a self-evaluation of your teaching, or other components of your teaching portfolio that can be constructive for your teaching career.

TeachingWe can support a variety of efforts to improve teaching institutionally, such as assisting in the design and implementation of evaluating teaching effectiveness (such as peer review), making sense of student evaluations of teaching, exploring and implementing research on pedagogies relevant to your discipline, developing discipline-specific teaching practices (signature pedagogies), establishing teaching award systems, and facilitating course design institutes, to name a few.

LearningWe can enhance student learning experiences by supporting student-centered design of curricular sequences and programs, facilitating reflection and research on learning, rethinking the effectiveness of learning spaces, and facilitating workshops or learning communities on learning issues, among other work.

CurriculumAlong with theOffice of Academic Program Review, Assessment & Accreditationwe can help you assess and evaluate your current curriculum or consider possible revisions to existing programs or launching of new programs.

Professional DevelopmentWe can support the professional development of your faculty and staff by creating plans for teaching improvement, recruitment and orientation of new faculty, mentoring junior faculty, fostering future faculty development processes for graduate students, and enhancing mentorship processes for instructors at all levels, just to name some examples.

AdvancED offers a diverse array of programs and services that: Apply research-based best practices and professional development. Nurture belonging through equity, inclusion, and caring communities of practice. Promote campus-wide collaboration between leaders, teachers, and learners. Design thoughtful curricula and organizational structures. Partner With Us Educational Design and Development Consultations Individual consultations are among the most beneficial services we offer. Each consultation is focused on your needs, allowing targeted approaches to address your teaching context and goals. These one-on-one consultations are designed to be formative, not summative, and therefore our staff or the information we discuss plays no role in any hiring, reappointment, tenure, or other evaluative process. Consultations can center on any teaching-related question that you have, but they often revolve around several core needs: Syllabus and Course Design Course design review is a valuable first step as you plan your courses and can bring an holistic and intentional approach to the development of multiple course components: your teaching philosophy, learning goals, assignments, learning activities, lesson plans, engagement techniques planning, course policies, or writing your syllabus, just to name a few. Instructional Design We can help you develop well-designed courses in Brightspace, Vanderbilt's learning management system, that can lead students to experience greater understanding, accessibility, organization, self-efficacy, and success. Teaching Observation Observations can be a highly valuable way to identify strengths and possible growth areas in your techniques of lecturing, leading discussions, designing lesson plans, engaging students, fostering inclusion and belonging, and countless other skills. This can be a way to become a more reflective and intentional teacher, and generate new ideas for effectively meeting your goals. This involves scheduling both an observation and a one-hour debrief. Technology Consultation Our team can help you think of what, if any, educational technology might help you innovate and better achieve your teaching goals, including Brightspace, Vanderbilt's learning management system, its associated tools, communications and networking technologies, presentation platforms, classroom response systems, audio/video technology, artificial intelligence, and much more. Teaching Portfolio We can help you reflect, assess, and develop a teaching philosophy, a self-evaluation of your teaching, or other components of your teaching portfolio that can be constructive for your teaching career. To set up a consult, complete our partner intake form below. If you prefer to meet with a specific team member review our team profiles below . If you need additional guidance, contact us via email or call us at 615-322-7290 and we will connect you to the right person. Partner With Us Collaboration with Departments, Programs, and Schools In addition to individual consultations, the Institute for the Advancement of Higher Education collaborates with department, program, school, and other unit leaders to support their curricular and organizational development. Our staff support collaborative initiatives that enhance student learning and faculty success. Below offers some examples of how we might be of service to you, but please complete our partner intake form to explore these or other needs and services. Teaching We can support a variety of efforts to improve teaching institutionally, such as assisting in the design and implementation of evaluating teaching effectiveness (such as peer review), making sense of student evaluations of teaching, exploring and implementing research on pedagogies relevant to your discipline, developing discipline-specific teaching practices (signature pedagogies), establishing teaching award systems, and facilitating course design institutes, to name a few. Learning We can enhance student learning experiences by supporting student-centered design of curricular sequences and programs, facilitating reflection and research on learning, rethinking the effectiveness of learning spaces, and facilitating workshops or learning communities on learning issues, among other work. Curriculum Along with the Office of Academic Program Review, Assessment & Accreditation we can help you assess and evaluate your current curriculum or consider possible revisions to existing programs or launching of new programs. Professional Development We can support the professional development of your faculty and staff by creating plans for teaching improvement, recruitment and orientation of new faculty, mentoring junior faculty, fostering future faculty development processes for graduate students, and enhancing mentorship processes for instructors at all levels, just to name some examples. Partner With Us Programs Besides our singular events, the Institute for the Advancement of Higher Education has a variety of longer, more comprehensive programs that provide educators with opportunities to learn more extensively about teaching and learning, and to become more effective educators. Learn more by clicking on the programs below which are updated periodically based on availability. Teaching at Vanderbilt Teaching Assistant Orientation Just-in-Time Teaching Workshops New Faculty Teaching Academy Academy of College Teaching Course Design Institute High Impact Series Workshops Interested but looking for other solutions? Check out AdvancED's other areas of support and services. Explore Digital & Lifelong Learning Dedicated to enabling high-quality, uniquely Vanderbilt programs our team can partner with you to plan, develop, and launch online or hybrid graduate degrees, and certificates. Learn more about digital & lifelong learning Explore Educational Technology Providing technical and pedagogical support for faculty, staff, and students our team is here to help you achieve your teaching and learning goals. Learn more about educational technology Our Team Jennifer Ogg Wilson Director Jennifer Wilson is the Director of the Office of Education Design and Development. As a Vanderbilt alumna with a Ph.D. and M.A. in Political Science, she is thrilled to be back on campus. A seasoned learning facilitator, she has created and led over 300 educational development workshops and programs for university faculty and staff. Her areas of expertise center around active learning, metacognition, student engagement and belonging, teaching innovation, and educational research. Her two most recent research projects explore the effects of personality on active learning and learning gains experienced by students taught through virtual reality. Prior to joining the OEDD in February of 2024, she was the Director of Teaching Programs at the University of Louisville. She also served for six years an Assistant Professor of Political Science at Tennessee Tech University, where she was the 2016 recipient of the Outstanding Teaching Award in General Education. Jennifer holds B.A.s in French and International Studies from the University of Tennessee, which support her favorite hobby of travel. Her other interests outside of higher education include downhill skiing, scuba diving, and cheering on the Kansas City Chiefs. Email Jennifer Brian DeLevie Associate Director Brian DeLevie is a digital artist, designer, author, and former Associate Professor of Design at the University of Colorado Denver. During his twenty-year tenure at the university, he served as the Co-Founder and Director of The Comcast Center for Media and Technology and the Center for Arts as Systemic Change, Chair of the Department of Visual Arts, and Head of the Digital Design program. As Associate Director, Brian liaisons with departments and colleges across the Vanderbilt campus and supports consultations, syllabus and course design, experiential education, workshops, teaching observations and programs such as New Faculty Teaching Academy. He also serves as a Senior Lecturer for The Department of Cinema & Media Arts. Brian’s body of creative and artistic works investigates themes of technology, memory, history, and Holocaust issues and has been exhibited and screened widely nationally and internationally and led to a Fulbright Fellowship to study the influences of Film, Television, and the Internet on German culture. With a Masters of Fine Arts in Electronic Arts/Design and an Ed.D in Leadership for Educational Equity in Higher Education, Brian has researched, presented, and published numerous papers investigating the confluence of design, memory, innovation, culture change, and experiential educational practices in higher education. Email Brian Bryson McGuire Manager of Teaching Development and Initiatives Bryson McGuire is the Manager of Teaching Development and Initiatives with the AdvancED team at Vanderbilt University. With a Doctor of Education (Ed.D.) in Learning Organizations and Strategic Change and a Master of Arts (M.A.) in Secondary Education, Bryson brings a wealth of knowledge and experience to his role. Throughout his career, Bryson has cultivated a leadership philosophy centered on trust, compassion, and collaboration. His diverse background includes roles as Interim Principal, Assistant Principal, Adjunct Professor, and Education Consultant, where he has consistently demonstrated his ability to lead diverse teams, create inclusive learning environments, and improve teaching effectiveness and student achievement. Bryson’s expertise includes leading collaborative initiatives that increased teacher-led activities and student engagement, as well as spearheading staff professional development sessions that enhanced student achievement scores and teaching effectiveness. He has a proven track record in supporting inclusive learning environments, managing diverse teams, and designing staff training sessions. In addition to his practical experience, Bryson is committed to community service and promoting equity, diversity, and inclusion. As a member of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc., and a board member of the Tennessee Pride Chamber, he actively promotes diversity and inclusion in professional and community settings. Email Bryson Marcy Pedzwater Instructional Design Manager Marcy is an Instructional Design Manager with the AdvancED team. With over five years of experience teaching and working in higher education, Marcy is passionate about creating and supporting high-quality learning experiences for students. Prior to joining Vanderbilt, she worked for the Writing and Learning Center at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. She holds a Ph.D. in English and Comparative Literature from UNC-Chapel Hill and a B.A. in Literature and a B.A. in Spanish from UNC Asheville. Outside of work, you can find Marcy knitting, crocheting, and going on hikes with her dog. Email Marcy Meg Pilkenton Education Development Specialist Meg Pilkenton is an Education Development Specialist for the Teaching Development and Initiatives team in the Office of Educational Design and Development. She leads the Academy of College Teaching and supports AdvancED’s educational development programming. She is passionate about active learning, critically reflective course design, and inclusive pedagogy. She holds a PhD in English from the University of Texas at Austin, where she spent six years teaching undergraduate courses in English and rhetoric as well as training graduate instructors. She’s also really into reading, her giant cats, and the fiber arts. Email Meg Lisa Lei Instructional Designer Lisa is an Instructional Designer with the AdvancED team. She is passionate about creating innovative, multimodal learning experiences and leveraging new technologies to promote educational equity. Prior to joining Vanderbilt University, Lisa served as an Instructional Technology Assistant at the Columbia Video Network. She also gained Instructional Design experience from Columbia University and iFLYTEK, a leading AI technology company in China. Additionally, she taught AP Psychology to students from five different countries. Lisa holds a Master of Education degree in Instructional Technology and Media from Teachers College, Columbia University, as well as a Bachelor of Science in Bilingual Education and a Bachelor of Arts in Psychology from Boston University. Email Lisa Grace Carlson Instructional Designer Grace is an Instructional Designer within the AdvancED team. Prior to joining Vanderbilt, Grace worked as a high school chemistry and physics teacher at Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools. Her experience in the classroom has driven her passion for creating accessible and engaging materials for all learners. Grace holds a Master of Education in Secondary Education from Vanderbilt University and a Bachelor of Science in Chemistry from the University of Wisconsin – Madison. In her free time, you can find Grace spending time outdoors with her dog, trying out new restaurants across Nashville, or binging reality television. Email Grace Boni Yraguen Instructional Consultant Boni Yraguen started with the Educational Design & Development team in August of 2023. Originally from Oregon, Boni is an alumna of the University of South Alabama in Mechanical Engineering. She holds a PhD in Mechanical Engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology, specializing in Thermal Fluid Sciences, specifically Diesel Combustion. Boni’s academic pursuits also encompass the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning and Engineering Education. Her research delves into designing engineering assessments for higher-order critical thinking, integrating technical-reflection in the engineering classroom, fostering STEM faculty development, and graduate education. Boni has experience in teaching and developing both undergraduate and graduate lecture and lab courses. While her interests are diverse, her passion lies in teaching and engaging with students. During her leisure time, you can spot Boni embarking on road trips with her hairless cats (Fig and Oliver), practicing kickboxing, or mastering a new craft, presently quilting. At the CFT, Boni’s primary role will be to assist with our programs for graduate instructors, but she will support many of our faculty programs and services as well. Email Boni Juliet Traub Administrative Coordinator Juliet has been with the Office of Educational Development and Design (formerly the Center for Teaching) since October 2014. She provides financial and logistical support for the office, which includes scheduling teaching consultations and meetings, managing the center’s budget, tracking participation within courses, and assisting with the planning and implementation of events and programs. Juliet holds a B.A. in Spanish from Middle Tennessee State University. She previously worked at World View, a program at the University of North Carolina, where she served as program manager. Email Juliet Contact Us Have a question about our teaching support services or need assistance with something else? Please feel free to contact our team. Mailing Address PMB183 230 Appleton Place Nashville, TN 37203 Hours 9:00am - 4:00pm CST Monday - Friday Phone 615-322-7290 Email advanced-teaching@vanderbilt.edu Visit Us Situated at the corner of 19 th and Edgehill Avenues with the main entrance facing 19 th avenue, our team is located just one block from the 21 st Avenue pedestrian bridge, making it a short walk from central and Peabody campuses. Campus visitors can find parking near the building by using the campus parking map . 19th Avenue and Edgehill Imagine What's Possible. Whether you’re looking to try something new, wanting to better connect with your students or need to develop your curriculum for hybrid or online environments, 
AdvancED’s team of skilled practitioners is ready to support your next step. Email Marcy Meg Pilkenton Education Development Specialist Meg Pilkenton is an Education Development Specialist for the Teaching Development and Initiatives team in the Office of Educational Design and Development. She leads the Academy of College Teaching and supports AdvancED’s educational development programming. She is passionate about active learning, critically reflective course design, and inclusive pedagogy. She holds a PhD in English from the University of Texas at Austin, where she spent six years teaching undergraduate courses in English and rhetoric as well as training graduate instructors. She’s also really into reading, her giant cats, and the fiber arts. Email Meg Lisa Lei Instructional Designer Lisa is an Instructional Designer with the AdvancED team. She is passionate about creating innovative, multimodal learning experiences and leveraging new technologies to promote educational equity. Prior to joining Vanderbilt University, Lisa served as an Instructional Technology Assistant at the Columbia Video Network. She also gained Instructional Design experience from Columbia University and iFLYTEK, a leading AI technology company in China. Additionally, she taught AP Psychology to students from five different countries. Lisa holds a Master of Education degree in Instructional Technology and Media from Teachers College, Columbia University, as well as a Bachelor of Science in Bilingual Education and a Bachelor of Arts in Psychology from Boston University. Email Lisa Grace Carlson Instructional Designer Grace is an Instructional Designer within the AdvancED team. Prior to joining Vanderbilt, Grace worked as a high school chemistry and physics teacher at Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools. Her experience in the classroom has driven her passion for creating accessible and engaging materials for all learners. Grace holds a Master of Education in Secondary Education from Vanderbilt University and a Bachelor of Science in Chemistry from the University of Wisconsin – Madison. In her free time, you can find Grace spending time outdoors with her dog, trying out new restaurants across Nashville, or binging reality television. Email Grace Boni Yraguen Instructional Consultant Boni Yraguen started with the Educational Design & Development team in August of 2023. Originally from Oregon, Boni is an alumna of the University of South Alabama in Mechanical Engineering. She holds a PhD in Mechanical Engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology, specializing in Thermal Fluid Sciences, specifically Diesel Combustion. Boni’s academic pursuits also encompass the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning and Engineering Education. Her research delves into designing engineering assessments for higher-order critical thinking, integrating technical-reflection in the engineering classroom, fostering STEM faculty development, and graduate education. Boni has experience in teaching and developing both undergraduate and graduate lecture and lab courses. While her interests are diverse, her passion lies in teaching and engaging with students. During her leisure time, you can spot Boni embarking on road trips with her hairless cats (Fig and Oliver), practicing kickboxing, or mastering a new craft, presently quilting. At the CFT, Boni’s primary role will be to assist with our programs for graduate instructors, but she will support many of our faculty programs and services as well. Email Boni Juliet Traub Administrative Coordinator Juliet has been with the Office of Educational Development and Design (formerly the Center for Teaching) since October 2014. She provides financial and logistical support for the office, which includes scheduling teaching consultations and meetings, managing the center’s budget, tracking participation within courses, and assisting with the planning and implementation of events and programs. Juliet holds a B.A. in Spanish from Middle Tennessee State University. She previously worked at World View, a program at the University of North Carolina, where she served as program manager. Email Juliet Contact Us Have a question about our teaching support services or need assistance with something else? Please feel free to contact our team. Mailing Address PMB183 230 Appleton Place Nashville, TN 37203 Hours 9:00am - 4:00pm CST Monday - Friday Phone 615-322-7290 Email advanced-teaching@vanderbilt.edu Visit Us Situated at the corner of 19 th and Edgehill Avenues with the main entrance facing 19 th avenue, our team is located just one block from the 21 st Avenue pedestrian bridge, making it a short walk from central and Peabody campuses. Campus visitors can find parking near the building by using the campus parking map . 19th Avenue and Edgehill Imagine What's Possible. Whether you’re looking to try something new, wanting to better connect with your students or need to develop your curriculum for hybrid or online environments, 
AdvancED’s team of skilled practitioners is ready to support your next step. Learn more Accept Vanderbilt University Vanderbilt University Menu About Admissions Academics Research Campus Life News & Events Give Close Menu Vanderbilt University All Vanderbilt About This is Vanderbilt Quick Facts University Leadership Equity, Diversity & Inclusion History Contact A to Z Admissions Undergraduate Admissions Graduate & Professional School Admissions Financial Aid Academics Program Finder Schools & Colleges Residential Colleges Study Abroad Libraries Strategic Plan Research Centers & Institutes Research News Undergraduate Research Graduate School Research VUMC Research Campus Life Housing & Dining Health & Safety Organizations & Identity Centers Athletics Our Hometown - Nashville News & Events Vanderbilt News Research News Vanderbilt Magazine Events Accessibility Info In meeting its nondiscrimination obligations under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act, the University has developed this form to help ensure that individuals with disabilities are able to acquire information and perform online tasks through the use of the University’s websites. The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) include standards by which the web is made accessible to individuals with disabilities. Here at Vanderbilt, we strive towards compliance with WCAG 2.0, Level AA Success Criteria. Please use this form to report questions or concerns related to individuals with disabilities and their ability to access web content on the University’s website. You may also contact the University's Web Accessibility Coordinator at (615) 322–4705 (V/TDD). View Form Vanderbilt University Vanderbilt is a private research university in Nashville, Tennessee . It offers more than 70 undergraduate majors and a full range of graduate and professional degrees across 10 schools and colleges, all on a beautiful campus—an accredited arboretum—complete with athletic facilities and state-of-the-art laboratories. Vanderbilt is optimized to inspire and nurture cross-disciplinary research that fosters discoveries that have global impact.
